question.title: Is there a way to create a direct ByteBuffer from a pointer solely in Java?

node.contents: Have you looked at sun.misc.unsafe? It allows you to directly interact with memory.

astNode.text: Have you looked at sun.misc.unsafe? It allows you to directly interact with memory.

node.contents: I did take a look and didn't see of a way to create a direct byte buffer with sun.misc.unsafe. I did find a way to create a DirectByteBuffer and it's through reflection. Use java.lang.Class.getDeclaredConstructor to create a Constructor object, setAccessable to true and call newInstance with the appropriate parameters. Little janky but you don't have to write any JNI code.

astNode.text: I did take a look and didn't see of a way to create a direct byte buffer with sun.misc.unsafe. I did find a way to create a DirectByteBuffer and it's through reflection. Use java.lang.Class.getDeclaredConstructor to create a Constructor object, setAccessable to true and call newInstance with the appropriate parameters. Little janky but you don't have to write any JNI code.

node.contents: Or do I have to have a JNI helper function that calls env->NewDirectByteBuffer(buffer, size)?

astNode.text: Or do I have to have a JNI helper function that calls env->NewDirectByteBuffer(buffer, size)?

node.contents: What I do is create a normal DirectByteBuffer and change it's address.

astNode.text: What I do is create a normal DirectByteBuffer and change it's address.

elements.contents: Field address = Buffer.getDeclaredField("address"); address.setAccessible(true); Field capacity = Buffer.getDeclaredField("capacity"); capacity.setAccessible(true); ByteBuffer bb = ByteBuffer.allocateDirect(0).order(ByteOrder.nativeOrder()); address.setLong(bb, addressYouWantToSet); capacity.setInt(bb, theSizeOf);

units.rawText: Field address = Buffer.getDeclaredField("address"); addresssetAccessible(true); Field capacity = Buffer.getDeclaredField("capacity"); capacitysetAccessible(true); ByteBuffer bb = ByteBuffer.allocateDirect(0).order(ByteOrder.nativeOrder()); addresssetLong(bb, addressYouWantToSet); capacitysetInt(bb, theSizeOf);

node.contents: From this point you can access the ByteBuffer referencing the underlying address. I have done this for accessing memory on network adapters for zero copy and it worked fine.

astNode.text: From this point you can access the ByteBuffer referencing the underlying address. I have done this for accessing memory on network adapters for zero copy and it worked fine.

node.contents: You can create the a DirectByteBuffer for your address directly but this is more obscure.

astNode.text: You can create the a DirectByteBuffer for your address directly but this is more obscure.

node.contents: An alternative is to use Unsafe (this only works on OpenJDK/HotSpot JVMs and in native byte order)

astNode.text: An alternative is to use Unsafe (this only works on OpenJDK/HotSpot JVMs and in native byte order)
